abstract.text: An object that contains information the boot loader needs for booting macOS as a guest operating system.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The Mac auxiliary storage contains data used by the boot loader and the guest operating system. It’s necessary to boot a macOS guest OS.
When creating a new VM, use
to create a default initialized auxiliary storage.
The hardware model you use when creating the new auxiliary storage depends on the restore image that you’ll use for installation. From the restore image, use
to get a supported configuration. A configuration has a
After initializing the new auxiliary storage, set it on
must be identical to the one used to create the empty auxiliary storage., otherwise the behavior isn’t defined.
lays out data on the auxiliary storage. After installation, the macOS guest uses the auxiliary storage for every subsequent boot.
When moving or performing a backup of a VM, you must move or copy the file containing the auxiliary storage along with the main disk image.
To boot a VM created with
to set up the auxiliary storage from the existing file used during installation.
When using an existing file, the hardware model of the
must match the hardware model used when creating the original file.

abstract.text: Create virtual machines and run macOS and Linux-based operating systems.
An object that contains information the boot loader needs for booting macOS as a guest operating system.
Options you can set when creating new auxiliary storage.
Initializes an auxiliary storage object with data from the location at the URL you provide.
Creates an initialized Mac auxiliary storage instance that describes a specific hardware model at a URL you specify.
Initializes an auxiliary storage object with data from the location at the URL you provide.
The URL of the auxiliary storage on the local file system.
A specification for the hardware elements and configurations present in a particular Mac hardware model.
A unique identifier for a VM.
An object that describes the parameter constraints required by a specific configuration of macOS.
An object you use to install macOS on the specified virtual machine.
An object that describes a version of macOS to install on to a virtual machine.
This object represents the most fully featured configuration that’s supported by both the current host and by this restore image.
A class that describes start options for macOS VMs.
The platform configuration for booting macOS on Apple silicon.
The Mac auxiliary storage.
The Mac hardware model.
The base class for a platform configuration.
The environment attributes and list of devices to use during the configuration of macOS or Linux VMs.
Download a macOS restore image and install it in a new VM.

doc://com.apple.virtualization/documenta.title: Installing macOS on a Virtual Machine

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
